results.title: Science in bloom
results.creator_credit: Sydney Newman, Nicholas Balla and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Canada carries on”.
Montreal’s Botanical Gardens are a storehouse of the wonders of nature. From all over the world scientists have gathered a living collection of plants and flowers, providing delight for the casual visitor and rich material for the student of botany. The actual process of plant growth is revealed for us by the time-lapse camera. We see a practical result of the botanist’s work in British Columbia’s important seed industry. Children, too, at the Montreal Botanical Gardens, cultivating their own plots of ground, take part in the quest for the secrets of nature.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Sydney Newman, Nicholas Balla and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Science in a wine glass
results.creator_credit: John Kingsford-Smith, Kingcroft Productions and Jack Gardiner
results.brief_description: Shows in detail, through specially made glass tanks, how wine is fermented, how fermentation is arrested, how color is infused into the red wine from skin pigmentation, how champagne is made and how wine matures. Also demonstrates how cross-pollination is effected to produce new varieties of grapes.

results.title: Science goes wool-growing
results.creator_credit: Pagewood Studios, Cinesound, Litchfield TV and Roland Litchfield
results.brief_description: Deals with the use of chemicals and fertilisers in sheep raising. Opening with shots of the Commonwealth Fertilisers and Chemicals Ltd factory at Yarraville, Victoria, shows the manufacture of super-phosphate and other agricultural products. Reviews research and experimental work associated with the development of new materials. Describes ways in which graziers can achieve maximum benefit from chemicals and fertilisers.

results.title: Science goes fishing
results.brief_description: Scientists from Laval University and the Federal Fisheries Research Board carry on scientific research in Gaspe to improve cod-fishing. The film tells how much time and patience were needed before the fishing folk of the area would accept scientific methods of fishing.

results.title: Science frontier = Frontieres de la science
results.creator_credit: Christina L McCaughey and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: A film that shows the civilian application of technology developed by the Research Section of the Department of National Defense such as: SONAR respirators; Malcolm Horizon; freeze-dried food; cathodic hull protection; and combat glasses.

results.title: Science for the tropics
results.creator_credit: Richard Tamblind, Technical and Scientific Films and Tony Baker
results.brief_description: A look at the work of the Tropical Products Institute in London, an organisation which assists third world countries to exploit their natural resources commercially. The Institute also does much laboratory work relating to agricultural issues. The film contains quite technical examinations of several projects the Institute has been involved in.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Richard Tamblind, Technical and Scientific Films and Tony Baker

results.title: Science for the space age: waves and energy
results.creator_credit: Larry Yust, Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and Stanley Croner
results.brief_description: Explains that there are many kinds of waves, including water, sound, light and radio waves. Uses illustrations and experiments to show how waves carry energy from one place to another. Describes the relationship between frequency and wave length; and explains how radio waves carry information.

results.title: Science for life
results.creator_credit: Knight Films and Peace Committee of the Society of Friends (Quakers)
results.brief_description: A teenage schoolboy is engaged in the quest for scientific knowledge. Two senior scientists bring the boy face to face with the challeng of - science to what end - life or death? A straightforward dramatisation of a debate intended to arouse lively and useful discussion for teenage audiences.

results.title: Science fiction: towards the twentieth century
results.creator_credit: Roger Thompson, BBC-TV and Open University
results.brief_description: Explores the ways in which the social and technological changes of the 19th century led writers to think of the future world as a very different world from the present. Shows the themes which pre-occupied Victorians were taken up by writers of predicive fiction and projected into the 20th century and beyond. Shows excerpts from “Things to come” and book illustrations from “War of the worlds” and “Time machine”. Presented by Simon Eliot. Novel excerpts read by Patrick Troughton. Suitable for secondary level.

results.title: Science fiction: Jules Verne to Ray Bradbury... and beyond
results.creator_credit: Barbara Winard and Center for Humanities
results.brief_description: The three parts of these videos give a brief overview of science fiction through history. Clips from films and television programs are used as illustrations. “From Lucian to Jules Verne” traces the beginnings of science fiction in social satire and criticism with the works of Lucian, Thomas More and Swift until Jules Verne revived the genre by tapping into scientific possibilities. “From H. G. Wells to George Orwell” shows how H. G. Wells linked the old and the new science fiction writers, who developed the space opera, magazines, and the science fiction film, culminating in Orwell’s grim visions of the future. “From Isaac Asimov to Arthur C. Clarke” documents the influences of outside factors such as World War II, the cold war, Vietnam and the hippy experience of the 60’s in the works of Asimov, Heinlein, Herbert and Clarke. Teacher’s notes accompany the videos.
